user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ahc_echo:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
ahc_echo (void *cls,
          struct MHD_Connection *connection,
          const char *url,
          const char *method,
          const char *version,
          const char *upload_data, size_t *upload_data_size, void **req_cls)
{
  static int aptr;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;               /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) url;               /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) version;           /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) upload_data;       /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) upload_data_size;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (0 != strcmp (method, "GET"))
    return MHD_NO;              /* unexpected method */
  if (&aptr != *req_cls)
  {
    /* do never respond on first call */
    *req_cls = &aptr;
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  *req_cls = NULL;                  /* reset when done */
  response = MHD_create_response_from_callback (MHD_SIZE_UNKNOWN,
                                                80,
                                                &data_generator, NULL, NULL);
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, response);
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  *req_cls = NULL;                  /* reset when done */

```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The assignment '*req_cls = NULL;' writes to the caller-supplied pointer (req_cls is of type void **), i.e. it modifies the stored pointer value. MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 recommends pointing to const-qualified types where possible for objects that should not be modified. In this case the code intentionally needs to modify the pointee (set and reset the per-connection context), so a const-qualified pointee would be inappropriate. Therefore this fragment does not violate Rule 8.13. (A violation would occur if the pointer referenced immutable data but lacked const qualification.)
